prompt.p: A 65-year-old smoker with a 6-month history of worsening cough is found to have a plasma sodium of 129 mmol/l (normal range 135–145 mmol/l) on blood tests at his annual physical examination. He takes salbutamol, tiotropium bromide and beclometasone inhalers. His urine osmolality is greater than plasma osmolality. A diagnosis of syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (ADH) production is suspected.
Which of the following is the most likely underlying condition?

modalFeedback.p: Option D is Correct. See Targeted Learning for further information.
Option A is Incorrect. This does not usually cause SIADH.

Option B is Incorrect. SIADH can be caused by selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, carbamazepine, chlorpropamide and cyclophosphamide. There is no record of these medications in the patient's history.
Option C is Incorrect. This does not usually cause SIADH.
Option E is Incorrect. Cerebral haemorrhage, infection and trauma can rarely cause SIADH. However, subarachnoid haemorrhage is not suggested by the history.
